An experimental investigation of gravity-driven shale tectonics in
progradational delta
R. Mourgues a,⁎, E. Lecomte b, B. Vendeville b, S. Raillard c

a UMR CNRS 6112, University of Maine, 72085 Le Mans cedex 09, France
b UMR CNRS 8157, University of Lille 1, 59655 Villeneuve d'Ascq, France
c Total, 64018 Pau cedex, France

a b s t r a c t
a r t i c l e
i n f o

Article history:
Received 9 December 2008
Received in revised form 4 May 2009
Accepted 8 May 2009
Available online 15 May 2009

Many deltas exhibit gravitational deformation of their sedimentary cover. In these systems, the décollement
layers do not always consist of rock salt but sometimes of overpressured shale. Unlike salt, the efﬁciency of
detachment in shale depends on the magnitude of ﬂuid overpressures and it varies through time and space,
as rapid sedimentary burial progrades into deeper water. As a result, the gravity deformational domains are
progressively translated seaward. Sandbox models involving high air pore pressures were used to simulate
such gravity-driven shale tectonics in prograding deltas. Models were built with sand of various
permeabilities and air was injected to simulate the mechanical effects of ﬂuid overpressure. Our apparatus
for the injection of air allowed us to control subsurface pressures in space and time during the experiments,
and it was used to simulate the advance of the front of the overpressured domain during the sedimentary
progradation. In our models, sand kept obeying a frictional behavior, for medium to high pore pressures, and
the detachment appeared as very thin shear bands. Compressional belts that formed during the experiment
were dominated by asymmetric basinward-verging fore-thrusts, as is often observed in deep-water, shale-
detached foldbelts. Where the value of ﬂuid pressures approached that of the lithostatic stress, sand was
ﬂuidized, resulting in ductile strains analogous to what occurs in highly overpressured mobile shale. During
progradation, ancient buried thrustbelts were reactivated, thereby controlling later extension. During the
experiments, sand volcanoes, analogous to mud volcanoes, formed in relation with tectonic structures. Some
of them developed near normal faults but many of them formed directly above old buried thrusts.
© 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Keywords:
Niger Delta
Shale tectonics
Gravity deformation
Fluid overpressure
Progradational delta
Analogue model
1. Introduction

Many continental passive margins exhibit a gravitational deforma-
tion of the post-rift cover. This deformation often results from a
combination of gravity gliding and gravity spreading (Schultz-Ela,
2001; Rowan et al., 2004), accommodated by proximal extension and
distal shortening of the sediments. At the base of the sliding
sediments, the décollement layer can consist of post-rift salt or shale
that is overpressured. Detachments on salt occur in the Nile deep-sea
fan (Gaullier et al., 2000; Loncke et al., 2006), the Atlantic margins of
Mauritania, Angola (Brun and Fort, 2004; Fort et al., 2004) or the
Mississippi fan and the northern Gulf of Mexico (Wu et al., 1990;
Rowan, 1997; Rowan et al., 2004). In the Niger Delta (Weber and
Daukoru, 1975; Morley and Guerin, 1996; Cohen and McClay, 1996;
Hooper et al., 2002; Corredor et al., 2005; Briggs et al., 2006), the
Amazon fan (Cobbold et al., 2004) or the Mexican ridges (Weimer and
Bufﬂer, 1992), the detachments stand in shale that is probably
overpressured. By carrying part of the weight and so reducing the

0040-1951/$ – see front matter © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
doi:10.1016/j.tecto.2009.05.003

frictional resistance at the base of the sediments, the ﬂuid over-
pressures allow the cover to glide on gentle delta slopes.

Rowan et al. (2004) showed that the structural style of the
contractional fold belts depends largely on the nature of the décolle-
ment layer. Salt is often considered as a viscous material having a very
low strength. Consequently, it starts to deform very soon after its
deposition. It leads to symmetric detachment folds, shortened salt
diapirs and/or inﬂated and thickened salt massifs and nappes (Rowan
et al., 2004; Fort and Brun, 2005). In the case of shale, contractional
thrust and fold belts are dominated by asymmetric, basinward-
verging thrust imbricates and multiple detachment levels (Briggs
et al., 2006). The main difference between salt and shale comes from
their rheology. Salt rheology does not change with temperature, depth
of burial or strain. Its rheological behavior does not vary much through
time and space. On the contrary, shale is a plastic material and its
strength greatly depends on the magnitude of the pore ﬂuid
overpressure. If shale is highly overpressured and undercompacted,
it becomes mobile and deforms under low stresses, rising by
hydrofracturing the overburden and producing diapirs and mud
volcanoes (Morley and Guerin, 1996; VanRensbergen and Morley,
2000; VanRensbergen and Morley, 2003; Deville et al., 2006). If shale
is moderately overpressured or more compacted, it becomes more

rigid and frictional and the detachments take the appearance of thin
shear zones or faults (sharp detachment)(Morley and Guerin, 1996;
Briggs et al., 2006).
In a sedimentary basin, ﬂuid overpressure can result from several
mechanisms (Osborne and Swarbrick, 1997; Swarbrick et al., 2002)
that are mainly controlled by the depth of burial. Fluid overpressures
may result from a reduction in the pore space, caused by diagenesis or
compaction during burial or horizontal compression of tectonic origin.
They also result from an increase in the volume of pore ﬂuid resulting
from thermal dilation, mineralogical transformation (smectite to
illite) and hydrocarbon generation (for example, production of
thermogenic gas at depths of over 5 km) (Barker, 1990; Cobbold
et al., 2004). As soon as the generating mechanism stops, abnormal
pressures tend to dissipate because the rocks are permeable (Neuzil,
1986). As a result, overpressures occur at depth; they are likely to be
transitory and they may vary in space and time.
At basin scale, the front of the overpressured domain may advance
basinward as sediments prograde seaward. As a result, the gravity
deformational domains progressively migrate into deeper water (Fig.1).
The basinward limit of this deformation may not only be controlled by
the sedimentary wedge (McClay et al., 1998; Vendeville, 2005) but also
by the boundary between overpressured and normally pressured shale,
because of the increasing resistance to sliding.
For the last two decades, salt and shale tectonics have been
invariably studied with sandbox modeling by using silicone putty as a
décollement layer (Cobbold and Szatmari, 1991; Vendeville and
Jackson, 1992; Koyi, 1996; Ge et al., 1997a,b; McClay et al., 1998;
Gaullier et al., 2000; Brun and Fort, 2004; Fort et al., 2004; Gaullier
and Vendeville, 2005; Vendeville, 2005). Such viscous analogue
material is probably well suited for salt whose rheology remains
constant through time, but it appears inadequate to simulate the
deformations of shale that is highly space and time-dependent.
For several years, a new analogue technique involving pore ﬂuid
has begun to prove itself. This new technique consists of injecting
compressed air in sandbox models to reduce effective strength of
materials and produce efﬁcient detachments. The ﬁrst tests were
carried out by Cobbold and Castro (1999) and Cobbold et al. (2001)
performed the ﬁrst compressional experiments. Mourgues and
Cobbold (2003) have also used such models for demonstrating the
signiﬁcance of seepage forces in tectonics. More recently, the
technique was improved by Cobbold et al. (2004), Mourgues and
Cobbold (2006a,b) and was successfully applied to verify some of the
theoretical predictions for thrust wedges containing ﬂuid over-
pressures (Cobbold et al., 2009) and for gravitational spreading and
gliding above overpressured décollements. Mourgues and Cobbold

Fig. 1. Evolutionary model of ﬂuid overpressure and gravitational deformation in a prograding delta. Whatever the generating mechanism may be (compaction or hydrocarbon
generation), the front of the overpressured domain may advance basinward as sediments prograde seaward.

(2006a) used an apparatus which allowed them to control the
distribution of ﬂuid pressure in the models and thus, gravitational
instabilities of any desired shape could be triggered.
In this paper, we further explore the potential of this method by
applying it to the complexity of shale tectonics and particularly to the
gravitational instabilities in prograding deltas. We start by brieﬂy
describing the thin-skinned deformation resulting from slope
instabilities in the Niger Delta where overpressured shale provides
the necessary basal detachment. Then, we discuss the scaling of
models involving pore ﬂuid and we introduce a new apparatus that
allows us to control the pore ﬂuid pressures in space and time in basin
scaled models. Several experiments of prograding deltas are presented
and are used for discussing some aspects of shale tectonics and the
advantages versus the limits of this analogue technique.
2. Gravity shale tectonics: example from the Niger Delta

The Niger Delta is a good example of a regional gravity shale-
tectonics system and is one of the most proliﬁc hydrocarbon
provinces. The delta is located in the Gulf of Guinea (central West
Africa) and it is one of the largest modern delta-systems in the world
(Weber and Daukoru, 1975; Cohen and McClay, 1996; Hooper et al.,
2002; Briggs et al., 2006). It sits at the southern end of the Benue
trough formed during the Cretaceous opening of the South Atlantic.
During Cretaceous, the Benue trough progressively ﬁlled with Albian
and younger post-rift deposits and by the late Eocene, a delta began to
prograde over the continental margin (Doust and Omatsola,1989) The
delta now consists of a broadly arcuate sedimentary prism some
12 km thick and covering 140,000 km2 (Hooper et al., 2002). At the
base of the Tertiary section of the Niger Delta is the Akata Formation
which is of marine origin. It is composed of thick shale sequences that
are believed to contain source rocks, ranging in thickness from 2000 m
at the distal part of the delta to 7000 m beneath the continental shelf.
This unit exhibits anomalously low P-wave seismic velocities that may
reﬂect regional ﬂuid overpressures (Corredor et al., 2005) and it
provides a good detachment horizon for large gravity tectonics.
The Niger Delta is divided in two main lobes separated by the
Charcot Fracture Zone, a prominent ridge of oceanic basement.
Deformation in the delta has resulted from gravitational thin-skinned
instabilities that formed various structural zones (Fig. 2a,e) (Damuth,
1994; Corredor et al., 2005). An extensional province, on land and in
shallow water, is characterized by both basinward dipping and
counter-regional listric normal growth faults. Basinward of the
extension zone is a diapir zone that exhibits passive, active and
reactive mud diapirs that form mud volcanoes at the seaﬂoor (Graue,

Fig. 2. Structural styles in the Niger Delta. (a) Synthetic cross-section of the Niger Delta with the main structural zones. (b, c) Close ups of structural style of compressional domains.
Fold and thrust belts are characterized by basinward-verging faults which imbricate above one or more detachments (Rowan et al., 2004; Corredor et al., 2005). (d) Normal faults
formed directly above old buried thrusts (after (Ajakaiye and Bally, 2002). (e) Map of Niger Delta showing the main structural zones with approximate location of sections b–d.

2000). In the most distal part of the delta, folds and thrusts, of
compressional origin, occur in deep water (outer fold and thrust belt).
Between, these extensional and compressional structures, there is a
transitional domain characterized by detachment folds and basin-
ward-verging thrust faults (inner fold and thrust belt). Here, younger
extensional faults are often surimposed on older buried compres-
sional structures. Such phenomenon is probably caused by the
prograding shelf (McClay et al., 1998; Hooper et al., 2002; Corredor
et al., 2005) (Fig. 2).

Bilotti and Shaw (2005) showed that the contractional toe of the
Niger Delta acts as a critical-taper wedge similar to the fold and thrust
belts at active margins (Dahlen, 1990). The very low taper of the toe
may be due to a very weak basal detachment. Bilotti and Shaw (2005)
calculated that the basal detachment in the Akata formation is
strongly overpressured, with a ﬂuid pressure exceeding 90% of the
weight of the sediment. This overpressure may be caused by the
combined effects of disequilibrium compaction, tectonic stresses and
hydrocarbon maturation (Cobbold et al., 2009).
3. Principles and scaling of models involving ﬂuid overpressures

The principle of injecting compressed air into sandbox models to
simulate the effects of pore ﬂuid overpressures was ﬁrst used by
Cobbold et al. (2001). Recently, this technique was improved by
Mourgues and Cobbold (2006a,b) who described and discussed
scaling of such experiments. The main difﬁculty in modeling
geological deformations with pore ﬂuid comes from the coupling
between ﬂuid pressure, ﬂuid ﬂow and matrix deformation. To achieve
a proper scaling, Mourgues and Cobbold (2006a,b) considered the
governing equations for the solid matrix and for the ﬂuid.

For the solid matrix, they used the equation of equilibrium in terms
of effective stresses (Eq. (1)) and they obtained scaling ratios for
effective stresses (σ′ij) and ﬂuid pressure (P) in terms of scaling ratios
for density (ρ), gravitational acceleration (g) and length (L):

Aσ V
ij = Axj = ρgi −AP = Axi
ð1Þ

γσ = γLγργg
ð2Þ

where γL=Lm/Lr, γρ=ρm/ρr, γg=γm/γr (sufﬁxes m and r refer to
variables in model and nature).
According to these equations, ﬂuid pressures and effective stresses
scale in the same way. For the choice of analogue material, we assume
that sediments deform in a purely brittle way when they are
submitted to hydrostatic pore pressure. If one considers a Mohr–
Coulomb yield envelope for the sediments and a ratio γL for length
about 10−5, dry sand with small cohesion (b60 Pa) is a good analogue
material. Following previous analogue modeling, we used sand from
near Fontainebleau (Sand GA39, produced by Sifraco, France), and
from Bédouin, located in the Ventout area (BE01 sand, produced by
Sifraco, France). Sands of various grain sizes were used. The properties
are summarized in Table 1.
For the ﬂuid, Mourgues and Cobbold (2006b) showed that it is
impossible to achieve a proper scaling of transitory phenomena in a

ﬂow and to control the ﬂuid pressure.

sand model that is only a few centimeters thick. In nature, over-
pressures develop if some mechanism disturbs the hydrostatic state.
They may result from either a reduction in the pore space, due to
contraction of the solid matrix, or an increase in the volume of pore
ﬂuid (Swarbrick et al., 2002). However, as soon as the generating
mechanism stops, abnormal pressures dissipate because sediments
are permeable (Neuzil, 1986). In a sandbox model, 3 cm thick, made of
classical Fontainebleau sand, Mourgues and Cobbold (2006b) demon-
strated that it is possible to model the generation of ﬂuid over-
pressures by a compaction mechanism by using water as a pore ﬂuid.
In addition, Mourgues and Cobbold (2006b) pointed out that it may be

Fig. 4. (a) Numerical prediction of thickness of sand in the injectors for any desired distribution of ﬂuid pressure in the model. (b) Fluid pressure distribution in a sand wedge model
with constant basal air pressure. λ (ﬂuid pressure parameter) decreases under the shelf. (c) Fluid pressure obtained by regulating ﬂuid ﬂow within the injectors. λ is laterally
constant.

difﬁcult to model any changes in permeability during faulting. Finally,
the ﬂuid pressure in our models will be controlled only by the
boundary conditions, and transitory overpressures will be negligible.
For practical reasons, we followed Mourgues and Cobbold (2006b)
and we used air as a pore ﬂuid.
4. Experimental technique

For this study, we built a new apparatus (Fig. 3) that allows us to
control and modify the spatial distribution of ﬂuid pressure during an
experiment. The apparatus is larger than the previous one developed by

Mourgues and Cobbold (2006a,b) in order to carryout experiments with
progradation. Models are built on a 2×1 m table made of 800
rectangular tubes, each 5 cm wide. Each tube can provide a different
ﬂuid pressure. These tubes are linked by rubber-tubes to a series of 600
injectors that rest above a reservoir of compressed air. Each injector is
ﬁlled with a different thickness of sand to regulate the ﬂuid ﬂow and to
control the ﬂuid pressure (Mourgues and Cobbold, 2006a). During an
experiment, the reservoir and the injectors can be disconnected from
the upper table and removed. This allows us to change the thickness of
sand in the injectors and thus to modify the distribution of pressure in
the model (Fig. 3). At the end of an experiment, models can be wetted
and cut without any percolation of water into the sand in the injectors.
Within the models, the ﬂuid pressure distribution depends on the
pressure in the reservoir, the thickness of sand in each injector but also
on the permeability and the 3D shape of the sand model. To calculate
the thickness of sand for any desired distribution of ﬂuid pressure in
the model, we developed a 3D numerical application (Fig. 4). It solves
the equations of a steady 3D ﬂuid ﬂow in a porous medium by a Finite
Volume method (Patankar, 1980), and calculates the distribution of
ﬂuid pressures within the injectors of the apparatus and within the
model (Fig. 4).
5. Calibration of experiments

The experimental procedure for sandbox modeling with pore ﬂuid
is more complex than for models using silicon putty. The efﬁciency of a

Fig. 5. (a) Conﬁguration of the analytical model (see also Appendix A). (b, c) Results of analytical model. (b) Critical length of sliding sheet as a function of basal ﬂuid pressure λb
(ﬂuid overpressure ratio on the detachment) for various seaﬂoor slopes (α) and various cohesions of the basal detachment (cb). The basal detachment dip (β) is set to zero, the
coefﬁcient of friction in the sliding sheet (μ) and on the basal detachment (μb) equal to one. (c) Effect of basal detachment dip on the critical length and basal ﬂuid pressure λb.

detachment in a model made of sand alone depends on the amount of
ﬂuid overpressures. However, for very high pore pressure, sand is
ﬂuidized and bubbles can reach the surface creating pockmarks
(Mourgues and Cobbold, 2006a) or degenerating into devastating
explosions. Models are then partly destroyed. In order to avoid such
devastating explosions, it may be convenient to predict the pore ﬂuid
pressure required to trigger a slide for a given shape of model.

Gemmer et al. (2004) and Lehner (2000) used a balance of stresses
to predict the stability criterion of systems with a viscous substrate
overlain by frictional plastic sediments of laterally varying thickness.
We applied the same analytical approach to predict the pore ﬂuid
pressure required to trigger gravity instabilities in our sandbox
models. The analytical model is drawn in Fig. 5a and analytical
developments are summarized in Appendix A. The ﬂuid pressure
required to trigger a slope instability depends on (1) the length of the
sliding sheet, (2) the dip of the detachment, (3) the slope of the
wedge, and (4) the cohesion of the material used as a décollement
layer. Analytical solutions are calculated for models made of sand with
a 1 cm thick toe. According to Fig. 5b,c, the ﬂuid overpressure
necessary for the slide decreases as the length of the sliding sheet
increases. Each curve (Fig. 5b,c) has a horizontal and a vertical
asymptote. The horizontal asymptote corresponds to the minimum
length of the sheet required to trigger a gravitational instability. The
vertical asymptote indicates the ﬂuid overpressure necessary for the
slide of an inﬁnitely long sheet (inﬁnite slope model (Crans et al.,
1980)). According to Fig. 5c, the dip of the basal detachment seems to

be the ﬁrst parameter controlling the stability criterion. The effect of
the surface slope is less important.
Several constraints must be taken into account to scale the
analogue model: (1) If gravity deformation progrades with sedimen-
tation on a table 2 m long, the sliding sheet must not be longer than
around 70 cm (in order to allow progradation). (2), ﬂuid over-
pressures must not exceed 0.95 on the basal detachment during
sliding to avoid devastating explosions in the extensional part (ref
Mourgues and Cobbold, 2006a,b). According to Fig. 5, it may be
impossible to trigger a 70 cm long slide with a horizontal basal
detachment and moderate surface slope (b15°). In addition, air
humidity in the experimental room may add some cohesion in sand. A
small increase of sand cohesion (20 Pa) is responsible for a large
increase of the ﬂuid pressure required for triggering the slide (Fig. 5b).
For all these reasons, our experiments were carried out with a basal
dip of 3.5°.
6. Experimental set-up

The experiments were designed to simulate progradational deltas.
Models were 1.8 m long and 60 cm wide. Each model was constructed
between two lateral glass walls and was built in successive layers of
various sands to create non-linear proﬁles of pore pressure (Fig. 6e).
Fig. 6a shows a schematic section of an undeformed model. The
bottom layer was uniformly 1 cm thick and was made of coarse sand
(Table 1 for properties). The next layer, 8 mm thick, was of ﬁne sand
and had a smaller permeability. Detachments occurred in this ﬁne
sand layer for high basal pore ﬂuid pressure because of the kink-like
proﬁle of pore pressure (Fig. 6e). This ﬁne sand layer is assumed to
simulate overpressured shale in nature. The models were then
covered by a third layer of coarse sand, uniformly 0.5 cm thick. An
initial proximal ﬂat shelf, 60 cm long and 1.5 cm thick, of coarse sand
was added at the back of the model. This shelf ended in a seaward-
thinning sand wedge (Fig. 6a) dipping at 6–7°. Later in the
experiment, several successive wedges of alternating colored coarse

Fig. 6. Experimental set-up: (a) models are multilayered, built with coarse and ﬁne sand (see Table 1). (b) Gravitational instabilities are triggered by increasing ﬂuid pressure in
speciﬁc parts of the models (c) During deformation, extensional grabens were sequentially ﬁlled to simulate synkinematic sedimentation and to compensate for thinning of
overburden and to avoid explosions. (d1–d2) Progradation of deltaic sediments is simulated by depositing a new sand wedge. A new injection window is then deﬁned assuming that
ﬂuid overpressure remains constant into the initial proximal shelf (d1 — Experiment 1) or decreases at the back of the proximal shelf while progradation occurred towards the basin
(d2 — Experiments 2 and 3). (e) Kink-like proﬁle of pore pressure in multilayered model. Detachments occur at the base of the ﬁne sand layer.

sand layers were deposited in order to simulate the progradation of
delta sediments (Fig. 6d). Although, the progradation front in natural
deltas is commonly lobate, we used linear fronts in our models.
Deformation was thus assumed to be only 2D. Between two successive
phases of progradation, gravitational collapse was triggered by in-
creasing the ﬂuid pressure in deﬁned parts of the models (Fig. 6b,c),
assuming that ﬂuid overpressures develop principally in high
sedimentation rate areas. During an experiment, the shape of the
injection window and the amount of ﬂuid overpressure evolved in
space and time as a consequence of the progradation (Fig. 6d1,d2). In
such analogue experiments, there is no time scale because viscous
silicon putty is not used and because transitory ﬂuid pressures are not
scaled. As a consequence, experiments are not continuous in time.
Gravity deformations are triggered by slowly increasing the air
pressure in the area where ﬂuid overpressure is assumed to develop.
When the required ﬂuid pressure is reached, a part of the model
suddenly slides. Extensional faults develop at the upper part and
thrusts form at the lower edge of the injection window. During
deformation, extensional grabens that formed on the wedge top were
sequentially ﬁlled in order to simulate synkinematic sedimentation
and in order to compensate for thinning of overburden and to avoid
explosions (Fig. 6c). On increasing the air pressure once more, the
slide advances another step. This procedure is repeated several times
until the increasing resistance at the toe prevents any new slide. At
this stage, the experiment is temporarily stopped, ﬂuid overpressure is
set to zero and a new sand wedge is built to simulate sedimentary
progradation. A new injection window is then deﬁned according to
the new shape of the model and ﬂuid pressure is increased again to
trigger new gravity deformations.
In all the experiments, the distribution of pore pressure in the
injection window was deﬁned to provide a uniform parameter λ (ratio
between pore pressure and lithostatic stress) at the base of the ﬁne
sand (Fig. 4c). Outside the injection window, pore pressure was
maintained at the atmospheric pressure, which is equivalent to a
hydrostatic state under water. We conducted three different

experiments of gravity deformation. At the end of each experiment, all
injectors were unplugged and models were wetted and sectioned to
obtain cross-sections.
7. Experimental results
7.1. Experiment 1

In this experiment, we assumed that ﬂuid overpressure remained
constant into the initial proximal shelf during progradation of the
sediments. After each sedimentary progradation, we increased
the length of the overpressured area according to the new shape of
the delta front and we kept constant the ﬂuid pressure at the back
of the model (Fig. 6d1). At the beginning of the experiment, the
injection window was 70 cm long. Its lower edge was 10 cm beyond
the talus. Four slides were triggered and three progradations, each
20 cm towards the basin, were done. Fig. 7b shows some photographs
of the upper surface, and their structural interpretations. For each
gravitational instability, an extensional domain appeared at the upper
edge of the overpressured area and fore-thrusts developed at its lower
edge. During the experiment, the extensional domain remained at the
same place but the compressional domain migrated basinward in
response to the increasing length of the overpressured area. After each
progradation, new fore-thrusts appeared and only one buried thrust
was reactivated (Fig. 7b-2). Several sand volcanoes developed that
were linked to normal faults (Fig. 7a) and thrust faults (Fig. 7b,c).
Some of them appeared in the extensional grabens because of a
decrease of the lithostatic stress, but most of them developed straight
above old buried thrusts (Fig. 7b). To avoid devastating explosions,
each pockmark was covered by a ﬁne layer of sand in order to stop its
activity. However, some of the volcanoes remained active and
effusions of ﬂuidized ﬁne sand continued. In such a case, the injector
just behind the volcano was unplugged in order to locally decrease the
ﬂuid pressure. After four successive stages of progradation and
gravitational instability, the experiment was stopped because it
seemed to be impossible to produce any new instability without
triggering explosions.
In cross-section (Fig. 7a), three structural domains are distinct. The
extensional part is 30 cm large. Extension is principally accommo-
dated by basinward-verging normal faults and only two or three
conjugated faults developed. The youngest normal faults are localized
just beyond a zone where ﬁne sand has disappeared due to extension.
This part of the model remained stable during the last episode of
gliding because the ﬁne sand was absent. In the transitional part, the
model is slightly deformed. On the right of Fig. 7c, the thickness of the
ﬁne sand remains uniform but the layer progressively thickens on the
left to form a large and ﬂat dome. The upper cover draws a large fold.
Six fore-thrusts developed in sequence forming the compressional
part. In the central part of the compressional domain, fore-thrusts root
on a strongly thickened ﬁne sand layer. From this thick mass of ﬁne
sand, two small pipes reach the surface (Fig. 7d). This proves that the
ﬂuid pressure was higher than the lithostatic pressure and that the
ﬁne sand was ﬂuidized.
7.2. Experiment 2

In the second experiment (Fig. 8), the overpressured area had a
constant size, but it migrated basinward following the progradation
(Fig. 6d2). In other words, ﬂuid overpressures progressively decreased
at the back of the proximal shelf while progradation occurred towards
the basin. Seven new prograding wedges, each 10 cm basinward, were
deposited, and a total of eight successive gravitational instabilities
occurred. As in the ﬁrst experiment, fore-thrusts systematically
developed at the lower edge of the overpressured area and an
extensional graben appeared at its upper edge. As a consequence,
normal faults and extension advanced basinward. After the third

progradation, extension was accommodated by second grabens that
occurred straight above ancient buried thrusts (Fig. 8b). In cross-
section (Fig. 8a), four structural domains are distinguishable. The
extensional domain is dominated by regularly spaced basinward
vergent faults. A small translational part, 20 cm long, is deformed by
only one normal fault. Compression is accommodated by eight fore-
thrusts which appeared in sequence during progradation. These
thrusts are distributed into two domains: a purely compressional part
where the youngest active thrusts developed (Fig. 8d) and a paleo-
compressional domain where old buried thrusts are cut by normal
faults (Fig. 8c). The extension above paleo-thrusts is expressed by
basinward vergent normal faults that intersect the ancient thrusts and
shift their tips. It results in bodies of coarse sand embedded in ﬁne
sand (Fig. 8c). Most of the ﬂuidization features took place in this
paleo-compressional domain (Fig. 8b).
7.3. Experiment 3

The experimental set-up for model 3 was similar to model 2, but
differing in the décollement layer. The 8 mm thick layer of ﬁne sand
was replaced by a 5 mm thick layer of coarse sand interbedded
between two 3 mm thick layers of ﬁne sand. This structure was
designed to obtain multiple detachments in the model (Briggs et al.,
2006). Surface deformations were very similar to Experiment 2. In
cross-section (Fig. 9), the same deformational domains are distin-
guishable. The extensional domain is dominated by regularly spaced
basinward vergent faults and antithetic faults only appeared above
buried thrust belts. In comparison with the previous experiments, the
compressional domain looks different because more back-thrusts and
pop-ups formed, probably owing to the different vertical pore ﬂuid
and strength proﬁles. Many ﬂuidization features are distinguishable in
the extensional and paleo-compressional domains. Fluidization seems
to occur preferentially in the basal ﬁne sand layer (Fig. 9a,c).
8. Discussion
8.1. Mechanical behavior of the décollement layer

Contrary to sand/silicone models, the mechanical behavior of the
sand in our experiments evolves in space and time as a function of
pore ﬂuid pressure. In Experiment 1, two fundamentally different
behaviors are distinguishable. In the translational domain (Fig. 7a),
detachment probably took place in the ﬁne sand layer. However, no
deformation of the markers is visible. Gravitational gliding of the
upper part certainly occurred on a very thin shear band parallel to the
stratiﬁcation (Mourgues and Cobbold, 2006a). In the left part of the
translational domain, the ﬁne sand layer locally thickens and forms a
large and ﬂat dome. The upper cover draws a large fold (Fig. 7c). In the
ﬁne sand, we observe that the black markers were sheared by very
ﬁne shear zones which do not propagate in the upper coarse sand. This
structure could result from a variation of the depth of the main shear
detachment due to a diffuse deformation at high ﬂuid pressure
(Mourgues and Cobbold, 2006b) and it could be interpreted as a broad
detachment fold. Such structures are common in shale-detached fold
belts of Niger Delta (Fig. 2c). In the compressional part of model 1, ﬁne
sand was ﬂuidized during deformation (Fig. 7d). Black markers
disappeared and the ﬁne sand layer thickened a lot at the base of the
thrusts. This thickening probably results from a ductile ﬂow of the
ﬂuidized sand towards the basin. Such viscous ﬂow happens in
gravitational deformations triggered by ductile material such as salt.
This ﬂuidization proves that ﬂuid pressure locally reached the
lithostatic stress. As a result, two sand volcanoes developed and
expelled ﬂuidized ﬁne sand. Two pipes ﬁlled with ﬁne sand are then
distinguishable in Fig. 7d. These kinds of intrusions of overpressured
material are current in basins where shale is overpressured (Van-
Rensbergen et al., 1999; Graue, 2000; Deville et al., 2006). Another

Fig. 7. (a) Cross-section of model 1. (b) 4 stages of surface structures and their interpretations. Dotted lines are the limits of overpressured windows (c) Close up of the detachment and the structure interpreted as a broad detachment fold.
(d) Close up of the compressional domain where ﬁne sand was ﬂuidized and formed two sand volcanoes (b3–b4).

Fig. 8. (a) Cross-section of model 2. (b) 8 stages of surface structures and their interpretations. (c) Close up of extension occurring directly above ancient buried thrust belt. (d) Close up of the compressional domain dominated by asymmetric
basinward-verging thrusts.

Fig. 9. (a) Cross-section of model 3 having multiple detachments. (b) 8 stages of surface structures and their interpretations. (c) Close up of the compressional domain where two detachments were active. (d) Pore pressure proﬁles in single
(models 1 and 2) or multiple detachments (model 3).

result of ﬂuidization of the décollement layer is that a block of coarse
sand detached from the roof of the ﬁne sand layer and fell in the
ﬂuidized sand (Fig. 7d).
8.2. Location of deformation

In all the experiments, the injection window seemed to control the
length of the gravitational instability. Fore-thrusts always developed
at its lower edge and extension appeared at its upper edge.
Consequently, active extension remained at the same place during
Experiment 1 but moved following the overpressured area in
Experiments 2 and 3. It indicates that gravity deformation is mainly
triggered by the general dip of the model and of its basal detachment
(Dahlen, 1990) and it is not signiﬁcantly inﬂuenced by the wedge
topography. In Experiments 2 and 3, the region of extension moved
towards the basin because ﬂuid overpressures decreased at the back of
the shelf. In nature, basal detachments are often horizontal or
sometimes they locally dip towards the shelf because of subsidence.
Gravitational instabilities are then triggered by the dipping surface
slope to reach its critical taper (Gemmer et al., 2004). Consequently,
regions of extension and contraction simultaneously form in the area
bounding the overburden slope (McClay et al., 1998; Vendeville,
2005). Moreover, ﬂuid overpressures mainly result from high
sedimentation rates of low permeable sediments. As soon as
sedimentation stops or decreases, abnormal pressures begin to
dissipate. In a prograding sedimentary margin, ﬂuid overpressures
may decrease at the back of the shelf where sedimentation rates
become smaller. Nevertheless, due to secondary generating mechan-

Fig. 10. (a) Numerical calculation of pore ﬂuid overpressure around a buried thrust. (a-1) permeability structure used for the numerical calculation. (a-2) Fluid pressure distribution.
(a-3) Distribution of ﬂuid pressure ratio (λ). Parameter λ reaches 1 under the buried thrust. This high value of pore pressure just under paleo-compressional structure favors the
formation of sand volcanoes and localizes extensional deformation. (b) Effect of seepage forces (forces due to overpressure gradients) and seaﬂoor slope on the orientation of
principal stresses and normal faults during extension. Non-vertical seepage forces in inclined sedimentary sequences are responsible for stress rotation (b-2) and inhibit reactivation
of ancient thrust faults.

isms (hydrocarbon generation), ﬂuid overpressures probably remain
high in these regions. Thus, an increasing size of the overpressured
area under the margin (Experiment 1) is certainly a more realistic
boundary condition than a displacement of the overpressure (Experi-
ments 2 and 3). In such conditions, the displacement of the exten-
sional part may only result from a basinward movement of the
sedimentary slope above a quasi-horizontal décollement layer (McClay
et al., 1998; Vendeville, 2005). To obtain such more realistic
deformations in overpressured sandbox models, the frictional mate-
rial used for the décollement must have a lower strength than sand.
In Experiments 2 and 3, a second region of extension super-
imposed on older buried paleo-thrusts. This phenomenon results from
the progradation of the shelf. Such analogous structures were
modeled by McClay et al. (1998, 2003) and are recognized in the
Niger Delta (Fig. 2d). This location of extension indicates that the
detachment was locally more efﬁcient, an observation that is
conﬁrmed by the formation of several antithetic normal faults
(Mourgues and Cobbold, 2006a,b). Fig. 10 shows the results of a
numerical calculation of ﬂuid pressure around a buried thrust in an
experiment. We observe that ﬂuid overpressure slightly decreases just
above the thrust, but it increases just under it. Mourgues and Cobbold
(2006b) have shown that a higher contrast of ﬂuid pressure between
the décollement layer and the upper sediments favors efﬁciency of the
detachment.
Contrary to what was expected, the fore-thrusts were not
reactivated by normal faults (Faccenna et al., 1995), instead, they
were cut by normal faults. It probably comes from an unfavorable
orientation of the principal stress due to ﬂuid overpressures.

Mourgues and Cobbold (2003) showed that ﬂuid overpressure
gradients add body forces in the sediments (seepage forces) that
modify the principal directions of stresses. In a sloping sedimentary
sequence, seepage forces inhibit the reactivation of older fore-thrusts
because the principal effective stresses are not favorably oriented
(Fig. 10). We can imagine that in non-tilted sedimentary sequence,
seepage forces do not change orientation of stresses and that fore-
thrusts could be reactivated more easily.
8.3. Structural style of contractional domains

The structural style of fold belts developed above salt décollement
depends on the thickness of the viscous layer. Above thick salt,
symmetrical detachment folds and shortened diapirs develop (Rowan
et al., 2004; Fort and Brun, 2005). Inﬂated and thickened salt massifs
and nappes are also common. If salt is thin, it has insufﬁcient volume
to ﬁll the cores of detachment folds and the shortening is
accommodated by reverse faults. The faults typically are vergent in
both directions but may have an asymmetric vergence. Nevertheless,
Rowan et al. (2004) underlined that gravity-driven thrust belts above
thin salt are rare because early loading and deformation generally
result in distal salt inﬂation. Many deep-water fold and thrust belts
detached above overpressured shale are characterized by basinward-
verging faults that imbricate above one or more detachments (Fig. 2a,
b,c). This asymmetry typiﬁes frictional detachments. Such asymmetric
basinward-verging thrusts are well reproduced in our model 2. Some
other shale-detached fold belts are characterized by symmetrical
detachment folds (Mexican Ridges) whose cores are ﬁlled with highly
overpressured mobile shale. In model 1, the ﬁne sand also thickened
signiﬁcantly in the compressional part. This probably resulted from a
ductile ﬂow of the ﬂuidized sand towards the basin. Nevertheless, the
thrusts are all basinward-verging and no antithetic fault appeared. It
may indicate that ﬂuidization and ductile thickening occurred after
the formation of the thrusts. In the Mexican ridges, the asymmetry has
also been interpreted as an early start of deformation while the shale
was still relatively strong (Rowan et al., 2004). Multiple detachment
levels are also common in shale-detached thrust belts of the Niger
Delta (Corredor et al., 2005; Briggs et al., 2006). In model 3, two layers
of ﬁne sand controlled the deformation and the structural style of the
contractional belt. Two detachments formed, but the upper décolle-
ment was less efﬁcient and it was active only in the compressional
part. In this domain, it seems to locally control the formation of back-
thrusts. Some ramps between the two detachments are also observed.
The vertical ﬂuid pressure proﬁle in the model is in Fig. 9d. Because air
is injected at the base of the model, the ﬂuid pressure (λ) is maximum
at the base of the ﬁne sand. As a consequence, most of the faults root
on the basal detachment. Moreover, according to the ﬂuid proﬁle in
Fig. 9d, the layer with low strength is probably thicker in model 3 than
in models 1 and 2. Consequently, it was probably easier to contract the
sand cover in model 3 and trigger a slope instability. It could also
explain the formation of pop-ups that requires very small strength of
the décollement.
8.4. Sand volcanoes and explosions

During all the experiments, several sand volcanoes developed and
ﬂuidized ﬁne sand was expelled (Figs. 7b and 8b). These structures
commonly appear in non-cohesive material if ﬂuid pressure exceeds
the lithostatic stress. Their location was mainly controlled by tectonic
structures. Some of them developed near normal faults and others
took place in the contraction belt. In the grabens, volcanoes formed
because of a decrease of the lithostatic stress during extension. Some
of the volcanoes formed directly above old buried thrusts because of
an increase of the ﬂuid pressure under these faults (Fig. 10). Many
mud volcanoes have been described on passive margin and over-
pressured deltas. These structures also develop in relation with

normal faults (Graue, 2000), thrusts or buried structures (Deville
et al., 2006). Nevertheless, despite some similarities with our sand
volcanoes, we think that the physical processes in our models are not
yet properly scaled. For example, mud volcanoes commonly develop
during thrusting because mud is compressed and ﬂuid pressures reach
the fracturing pressure (Deville et al., 2004). In our models, the
increase in ﬂuid pressure around thrusts is induced by local thickening
of the ﬁne sand layer, thus is not a real coupling between the
contraction and the increase in ﬂuid pressure. Moreover, because the
eruption of such sand volcanoes greatly damages the models, we
preferred to inhibit their formation as much as was possible.
9. Conclusion

Analogue models involving pore ﬂuids were tested to simulate
gravitational deformations and shale tectonics in a progradational
sedimentary delta. Our models have some advantages in comparison
with models involving silicone putty as décollement. Deformation of
overpressured sand depends on the magnitude of the ﬂuid over-
pressure and, thus, it approaches the behavior of overpressured shale.
For moderate to high pressures, sand has a frictional behavior.
Detachments looked like very ﬁne shear bands and compressional
belts are dominated by asymmetric basinward-verging thrusts as it is
often observed in shale-detached fold belts. For ﬂuid overpressures
approaching lithostatic stress, sand is ﬂuidized and behaves like a ﬂuid.
It results in local thickening of the décollement due to ductile ﬂow of
the ﬂuidized ﬁne sand. These deformations are analogous to what
happens in highly overpressured mobile shale. Sand volcanoes which
are analogous to mud volcanoes also formed in our models. They
expelled ﬂuidized ﬁne sand. Moreover, our technique allows us to
control ﬂuid pressure in space and time so it is possible to test the
structural consequences of various ﬂuid pressure distributions and
evolutions. Such a method may be suitable for “scenario” modeling.
Nevertheless, our method has some limits. It seems difﬁcult to
simulate slope instabilities on a very gentle slope (b2°) without
triggering sand volcanoes and devastating explosions. Less frictional
material will have to be tested. Moreover, ﬂuid pressure and
deformations are not fully coupled and it may be an important
phenomenon during thrusting. By increasing viscosity of the pore ﬂuid
and by decreasing the permeability of the granular material, it would
be possible to approach such coupling for more realistic modeling.

Lehner (2000) and Gemmer et al. (2004) used balance of stresses

instability. Let us consider the model of laterally varying thickness
in Fig. 5a. The sheet abuts a normal fault as its trailing edge and a
thrust fault at its leading edge. The balance of forces parallel to a β
degrees dipping detachment gives the stability criterion. The sheet
becomes unstable when:
